STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 15, 2024
Melissa VanLuven
SAULT TRIBE BINOGII - PLACEMENT
2218 SHUNK RD,
SAULT S MARIE, MI, 49783-9467
RE: License#: CN170201399
Dear Ms. VanLuven:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 05/09/24 Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, Area Manager, at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Douglas Turrill, Licensing Consultant
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City MI 49684
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

adoption, Place children in foster home,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor,
when siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who
are a member of a participating household. • Youth
ages 14 and older. • Foster parents, relative
caregivers, and unrelated court ordered caregivers
Six files and 16 service plans were reviewed. Two of six files contained one or more
Parent Agency Treatment Plans (PATP’s) that were signed late. Therefore, the
signature pages were not uploaded into the electronic case record within 30 days of
the report date.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
06/02/2023 Interim. CAP approved 07/13/23.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for
the following:

• Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, checking it for accuracy, identifying areas
needing follow-up, and recording the outcome data.
• Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, to all participants (in person and by phone),
legal parents, and casework supervisor. These
documents must also be uploaded into the
electronic case management record.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
the electronic case management record using the
FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the
FTM.
Six files were reviewed. Two of six files did not have the uploaded DHS-1105 within
7 business days. One of six files documented an FTM beyond 30 days of the
service plan due date.
FOM 722-06H Case contacts

Quality visits between the case manager and child
have been found to produce positive outcomes for
children in care. A quality visit is defined as one in
which the case manager:
• Can meet with each child individually, without the
presence of other individuals, to give the child an
opportunity to ask questions as well as discuss the
current placement.
• Views the child's bedroom and sleeping
arrangements.
• Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for
infants under 12 months.
• Assesses each child’s educational, medical,
dental, mental health, and other needs and takes
appropriate action or offers services in response to
the identified needs of each child.
• Shows interest in the child to build and establish
rapport.
• Shares and explains the case plan, including the
plan for parenting time, visits with siblings and other
relatives, and the child's permanency plan, in a
developmentally appropriate way while allowing the
child to ask questions and express viewpoints.
Six files were reviewed. One of six did not verify safe sleep requirements.
FOM 801-03 Medical passport
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
Six files were reviewed. Three of six files did not consistently document that
quarterly updates were completed.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was provided regarding Rule 400.12209 (2), (a),
orientation and training. The agency was informed that training under this rule
subsection is required yearly for workers carrying a caseload.
• Technical assistance was provided regarding Rule 400.12415 (a). The
agency was informed that incident reports are to be submitted to the DCWL
Consultant. Only those incidents identified under the rule are required to be
submitted.
• The agency was informed that starting January 1, 2024, interim and renewal
corrective action plans will be reviewed by the consultant at three months and
six months. Then process for review was explained to agency administration.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or offered at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the CAP is as follows. The agency
submitted an approved corrective action plan on 07/13/23 in response to those
violations established during the 06/02/23 interim inspection. The current renewal
inspection established one repeat violation indicating the agency CAP was
successful in preventing repeat violations of the other four rule violations
established in the interim inspection. There were no complaints against the
agency during the licensing period.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was submitted and reviewed. The
assessment identified barriers such as the significant data requirements and
spread sheets required for submission by the State. Other barriers included Tribal
information that does not always connect easily with State processes making for
extra work for staff and administrators.
The assessment also notes that in working with MISACWIS progress has been
made but the nuances of MISACWIS often create extra work for staff. Among

other barriers is the problem of finding medical and dental providers over the
mostly rural area the agency serves.
Financial Overview
Financial records including a certified public accountant audit was submitted and
reviewed. There were no noted concerns.
Staff Interviews
Staff interviewed reported liking working for the agency and they feel they are part
of a supportive team. Staff reported that their supervisors are knowledgeable and
always available for support.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is located in a modern facility on tribal land. The building is well
maintained and spacious. CHRI documents were observed to be stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst generated a safety alert on 02/26/24 as she was not permitted to
visit a relative home located on tribal trust land.
Resolution: This was obtained on 02/26/24 when an agency worker visited the home
and verified that fire and carbon monoxide alarms were in place and operational.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
May 14, 2024
_____________________________________
Douglas Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 15, 2024

Samantha Way Date
